image.altText: A man walks our of a building, he is looking down and wearing a suit and a face mask.

props.synopsis: Former childcare worker Muhammad Ali, 31, will be sentenced for the 2022 abuse of the boy on Thursday.

title.children: Parents of boy abused by former childcare worker describe 'tainted lives'

image.altText: A composite image of two men, both wearing black sunglasses, walking outdoors looking serious.

props.synopsis: Lawyers for a Canberra man charged with raping a teenager in 2022 have told a jury there is a real chance if found guilty he would be taking the fall for someone else.

title.children: Canberra man on trial for raping teenage girl calls co-accused a 'liar'

image.altText: Gungahlin United Football Club

props.synopsis: Families have been left "totally blindsided" by the closure of Gungahlin United Football Club, as the club's debts more than double to $550,000.Â

title.children: 'Shattered': 2,000 players left stranded as football club's debt doubles

image.altText: a close-up of someone using an iphone to purchase alcohol online

props.synopsis: The ACT government introduces a bill that would restrict alcohol deliveries to Canberra homes to between 10am and 10pm, and cap the amount of alcohol a consumer could receive in a 24-hour period.

title.children: Alcohol deliveries to Canberra homes could soon be restricted

image.altText: The ACT Supreme Court towards dusk.

props.synopsis: A Canberra man has pleaded guilty to his part in a "cruel" and "premeditated" attack on a woman, helping trick her into a car before driving her around, hitting her with a baseball bat, choking her and demanding $10,000.

title.children: Canberra man jailed for part in brutal baseball bat attack

image.altText: A man wearing a navy suit and glasses stands behind a podium looking serious.

props.synopsis: The ACT's chief minister brushes off criticism that his government is "tired", but acknowledges the 12 months since the election have been "difficult" for the territory.

title.children: It has been a 'challenging first year' in minority government, says Barr

image.altText: A render of the new UNSW Canberra buildings

props.synopsis: Once complete, the new UNSW campus will be an education hub for thousands of students and staff, and is expected to provide a much-needed injection to the city's economy.Â

title.children: First look at UNSW's $1b Canberra campus expansion

image.altText: a man pulls a snake from its tail

props.synopsis: A passenger in a car has the fright of his life when a tiger snake slithers across his feet during a drive on the NSW far south coast.

title.children: 'Hell of a fright': Snake slithers over man's foot on drive to the shops

image.altText: A composite image of Mark Haines with railway tracks.

props.synopsis: Some key questions about the death of Indigenous teenager Mark Haines are still unanswered after a coronial inquest spanning five weeks.

title.children: After five weeks of evidence, this is what we know about the Mark Haines mystery

image.altText: A man covered in mud carrying a sack on his back while smoking a cigarette.

props.synopsis: Unlike the name suggests, rare earths are not very rare at all. The critical minerals are found in abundance in many countries, but being big on reserves may not mean big business.

title.children: Where in the world are all the rare earths?

image.altText: Bridget McKenzie - 2025-05-20 12:56:41

props.synopsis: Bridget McKenzie says she thinks Barnaby Joyce will remain in the Nationals party room after he left the door open to joining One Nation.

title.children: Nationals senator says 'malicious intent' behind Joyce One Nation push â as it happened

image.altText: A man hoses down dirt at a mining site

props.synopsis: America dominates the global financial system. The Middle East controls energy. And China, during the past 40 years, has created a vice-like grip on the mining, refining and production of global metals.Â

title.children: How China's heavy-handed rare earths threat backfired

image.altText: A wide shot of supermarket shop shelves

props.synopsis: The two biggest issues impacting business confidence continue to be wage costs and margin pressure, the NAB quarterly business report shows. BHP faces questions on China. Follow the day's events and insights from our business reporters on the ABC News live markets blog.

title.children: NAB survey points to inflation pressures

liveBlogKeyEvents.title: Modest fall for ASX at the open

image.altText: Trees down.

props.synopsis: Howling winds overnight will lead to extensive clean-up work today in NSW's south-east and parts of Victoria, with October heat records also broken in Western Sydney.

title.children: Parts of NSW and Victoria 'absolutely battered' by howling winds

image.altText: A crowd of people surround a truck, some are climbing on the truck.

props.synopsis: The International Court of Justice rules Israel must allow aid groups access to Gaza and that the nation's attempts to stop a UN agency delivering aid to Palestinians are illegal.

title.children: ICJ rules Israel must allow aid groups unimpeded access to Gaza

image.altText: A dark-haired man in a dark suit holds his hand to his chin.

props.synopsis: The International Chess Federation says it will examine Vladimir Kramnik's public attacks on Daniel Naroditsky, the American grandmaster who died at the age of 29 this week.

title.children: Ex-chess world champ facing probe over attacks on late grandmaster

image.altText: A basket lift outside the Louvre museum.

props.synopsis: The Louvre chief says she repeatedly raised concerns about CCTV coverage at the museum, only for her fears to come "horribly true".

title.children: Louvre chief blames CCTV gaps for $157m jewellery heist

image.altText: Broadmeadows train station sign

props.synopsis: Two teenage boys were hospitalised with stab wounds after an alleged brawl between two groups armed with a screwdriver and possibly a machete at a train station in Broadmeadows on Wednesday.

title.children: Teens stabbed in alleged screwdriver, machete brawl in Melbourne's north

image.altText: A bird with green grass stems on its face on a windy day

props.synopsis: The 40 shortlisted images pair talented nature photography with humour that often relies on clicking the shutter at just the right moment.Â

title.children: In need of a laugh? Check out the finalists of the Comedy Wildlife Photo Awards

image.altText: A tattooed man in goggles and a swim cap pats his chest, apparently before a race.

props.synopsis: Two weeks after after Mollie O'Callaghan was targeted, Swimming Australia has asked Meta to take down fake quotes attributed to Kyle Chalmers.

title.children: Swimming Australia takes aim at Meta over more fake quotes

image.altText: A school bus on fire on the side of a country road.

props.synopsis: A school bus in WA's South West burst into flames before the morning run. Thankfully, no children were on board at the time.

title.children: Driver has lucky escape as school bus bursts into flames

image.altText: A person pouring coffee and milk into a white coffee cup to make latte art.

props.synopsis: The Australian coffee industry is growing as new varieties become available and local demand increases.

title.children: More Australian-grown coffee on the horizon amid local bean boom

image.altText: Orange virus particles on a white and green dotted background

props.synopsis: Mpox transmission surged between July to September last year, but there have been far fewer cases recorded in 2025.

title.children: Mpox cases hit a record high in 2024. It's a different story this year

image.altText: Nathan Cleary stands with his hands on his hips

props.synopsis: The Ashes clash with England is a three-Test contest and Origin rivals Nathan Cleary and Harry Grant believe experience in the state head-to-head could be telling.

title.children: Origin experience a bonus in Ashes trilogy

image.altText: Two teenage girls alongside polaroid-style pictures of gymnastic performances

props.synopsis: Gymnasts as young as 13 say they were bullied, fat-shamed and humiliated at a Queensland gymnastics club, then forced out when their families complained.

title.children: Gymnasts allege body shaming, humiliation, before being forced out

image.altText: A man stands on a cricket field speaking to two players.

props.synopsis: Australian Cricketers' Association boss Paul Marsh will seek clarification from Queensland coach Johan Botha over his comments regarding player payments.

title.children: Coach under fire for suggesting injured cricketers should not be paid

image.altText: Person measuring their waist.

props.synopsis: The pharmaceutical giants behind Wegovy and Mounjaro have recently launched advertisements directing people towards their doctor for weight loss. Some experts warn this type of advertising may affect public health messaging.

title.children: Pharma companies accused of trying to 'undermine' Australian ad laws

image.altText: Silver and gold bars

props.synopsis: Precious metal prices have been pushing record highs and, as queues lengthened outside bullion traders, gold and silver prices suddenly fell back. But positive signs remain, analysts say.

title.children: A silver lining for investors rushing into precious metals

image.altText: Beryl sits outside in the sunlight in front of a tree, looking at the camera with an inscrutable expression.

props.synopsis: As the Northern Territory prison population continues to reach all-time highs, data reveals a majority of the NT's rehab program are being cancelled more often than they are being delivered.

title.children: NT prisons so crammed 'girls are sleeping at reception'

image.altText: Prince Andrew in ceremonial clothes looks out a rainy window

props.synopsis: Sir Keir Starmer has told British parliament he supports scrutiny of Crown property deals but getting Prince Andrew to answer questions at Westminster might not be easy.

title.children: UK PM backs calls for Prince Andrew to face MPs over Royal Lodge deal

image.altText: A man dressed in a wetsuit stands on a boat.

props.synopsis: It is estimated half of the local seagrass habitat in Gamay (Botany Bay) has already been lost. Researchers and Aboriginal rangers are replanting seagrass fragments and using biochar to restore the area.

title.children: 'Localised extinction' risk for seagrass in Botany Bay

image.altText: A woman looks at the camera smiling with her 10-month-old baby whose face is pixalated in this photo.

props.synopsis: As the European Union proposes a ban on the entire PFAS chemical class, some researchers say Australia should do the same.

title.children: Calls for Australia to follow Europe's push to ban 'forever chemicals'

image.altText: A close-up of fresh fish for sale at a market.

props.synopsis: There are microplastics in almost everything, so why does seafood get such a bad reputation? Scientists say it is down to disproportionate research and media attention.

title.children: Microplastics 'misconception' hurting seafood sector, scientists say

image.altText: A dark-haired, bearded man in a sports tracksuit holds an Israeli flag while raising his arms in triumph.

props.synopsis: The world's most populous Muslim nation refused to issue visas to Israeli athletes last week because of the war in Gaza.

title.children: Indonesia's ban on Israeli athletes sparks backlash from IOC

image.altText: A model with long dark curly hair, wearing a white head cap and a white dress

props.synopsis: Award-winning fashion designer Amy Lawrance blends 90s sci-fi with the medieval in her new collection, Total Recall.

title.children: Meet the Bendigo-born fashion designer blowing up in New York
